Ian Badcoe wrote:

>Hi,
>
>I don't think there really are any supercomputers any more, because 
>everybody has one on their desktop.  I certainly haven't heard about any 
>since the early 90's.
>
>When people want _serious_ computers these days, they look to 
>grid-computing in the style of SETI@Home.
>
>If you can do that, and get popular, you can get 1,000,000s of times more 
>CPU, but your job has to be dividable into appropriately sized chunks.
>
>         Ian Badcoe
>  
>
Hi Ian,

Grid computing is pretty cool but supercomputers still have a number of 
uses, especially for problems that require passing around large amounts 
of data (or small amounts very fast). Physical world simulations come to 
mind - things like weather systems and nuclear detonations, especially 
since actual nuclear tests are sort of frowned upon these days :)  Also 
I don't think any military organisation really wants their simulations 
distributed over the internet... or perhaps that what SETI is /really/ 
doing behind the scenes? ;)    I should keep schtum, I have a hunch 
there may be some military folk on this list. :-/

Colin
